results.title: Seeing Our Own Reflection in the Birth of the Self-Portrait
results.abstract: Now it seems self-evident that pictures can represent who you “really” are. That conviction began with Albrecht Dürer, five centuries ago.

results.title: Delay of Philip Guston Retrospective Divides the Art World
results.abstract: “Philip Guston Now” has become Philip Guston in 2024, after four museums postponed an artist’s show that includes Klan imagery.

results.title: Seeking the Humanity in the Story of Kim Wall’s Murder
results.abstract: A new TV series, “The Investigation,” fictionalizes the police investigation into the killing of the Swedish journalist, resisting the usual trappings of Nordic noir.

results.title: Philip Guston Blockbuster Show Postponed by Four Museums
results.abstract: The works that appeared to ignite concern include hooded Ku Klux Klan figures, a motif in Guston’s paintings since the early 1930s.

multimedia.caption: A Philip Guston retrospective has been postponed until 2024. The delay may have been rooted in concerns that trenchant works like “Edge of Town” (1969), which was shown at the Museum of Modern Art, show hooded Klansmen.
multimedia.copyright: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times
